description.narrative: The overall project objective is to to end rape and sexual violence among women and girls. The key outcomes are: 1) Increased knowledge among women, girls, community leaders, members and duty bearers on how to deal with rape and sexual violence and 2) Improved knowledge and practice to prevent rape and sexual violence and promote services to survivors of violence. The main problem being addressed by the project is as follows: In Zimbabwe, levels of Gender-based Violence (GBV) remain a concern and impediment to girls’ and women’s active participation in development. Despite the enactment of several protective laws and policies, such as the Domestic Violence Act of 2007, girls and women in Zimbabwe continue to be survivors in 99% of GBV cases. Most acts of violence are committed within the home or by partners. According to the Zimbabwe Demographic Health Survey (ZDHS) 2010-11, 42% of women in Zimbabwe have either experienced physical, emotional or sexual violence (or both) at some point in their lives.Rights holders for this project mainly include women and girls and women survivors of gender based violence.This project mainly falls within the Gender Equality intervention area (combating gender based violence objective) in the current Diakonia Zimbabwe’s Strategic Plan for 2016-2020. It will be implemented by Musasa Project Trust (Musasa) in Mwenezi rural district in Masvingo province and Beitbridge rural district in Matabeleland South province.
This project mainly contributes to results within Combating gender based violence. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
